newsitem.title: UK: UK '96 chocolate consumption seen up, exports down.
newsitem.headline: UK '96 chocolate consumption seen up, exports down.

text.p: UK 1996 chocolate consumption is expected to rise while exports slip, according to a report from the International Cocoa Organization's (ICCO) meeting here through Friday.
In a document obtained by Reuters, charts from the Biscuit, Cake, Chocolate and Confectionary Alliance (BCCCA) project 1996 chocolate consumption up to 550,290 tonnes, or 9.39 kilograms per head.
That would be up four percent from 529,435 tonnes, or 9.05 kilograms per head, in 1995, it said.

The expected 1996 rise would reinforce a clear up-trend in UK chocolate consumption over the past 10 years, excluding a marginal decrease in 1995 due to an exceptionally hot summer that curbed chocolate consumption, the report said.
Chocolate consumption fell in 1995 from 531,995 tonnes, or 9.11 kilograms per head, in 1994.
But chocolate exports are expected to drop in 1996 from year ago levels. The report forecasts exports of 112,305 tonnes, down from 114,465 tonnes in 1995 and 127,190 tonnes in 1994.
